aiContracts.title: AI Contract Checklist
aiContracts.description: AI vendors blur data rights, indemnity, and compliance, so the contracts need explicit clauses for training materials, discovery, and human oversight before you deploy the output.

items.title: Data sourcing & training rights
items.body: Given recent settlements over training data, it is essential to require vendors to warrant that no unauthorized proprietary or personal data is in the models and that they will document every dataset used for your deliverables.

items.title: Indemnity & liability
items.body: Insist on indemnities that cover IP infringement, regulatory fines, and misuse of likeness; cap liabilities only when the counterparty can prove a robust risk transfer strategy.

items.title: Transparency & audit
items.body: Ask for audit rights over training data, red-teaming outputs, and the logs showing when human review kicked in—without this you can never prove compliance or fulfill disclosure obligations to talent unions.

items.title: Operational guardrails
items.body: Include a mitigation plan that flags misuses (e.g., recreated likenesses, biased outputs) and anchors the vendor’s obligation to pause deployment until humans clear the content.

actionItems: Publish a vendor questionnaire that tracks datasets, red-team findings, and usage history for each piece of work.
Document human-in-the-loop checkpoints in the contract so the developer cannot claim the model is fully autonomous during audits.
Include a procedural review section that requires the vendor to document datasets, human oversight, and mitigation plans.
Draft a fallback clause requiring the vendor to pull down any unauthorized synthetic likeness upon notice.
Build a takedown remedy tied to the general AI policy so you can quickly remove unauthorized synthetic likeness.

aiInEntertainment.title: AI in Entertainment
aiInEntertainment.description: AI is already reshaping production, publicity, and talent rights. Here is a quick look at where the technology is live, how regulators and unions are responding, and what you should lock into your process.

snapshots.title: Digital replica consent is now non-negotiable
snapshots.body: Most new SAG-AFTRA agreements require companies to get clear consent and compensation for digital replicas, commercials, and interactive characters before using AI avatars or likenesses, so talent teams lock in the scope of use up front.

snapshots.title: Interactive media and games have AI guardrails
snapshots.body: The 2023 interactive media addendum projects into episodic series and games, requiring disclosure when synthetic voices or faces replace an actor and ensuring performers can audit how the material is generated.

snapshots.title: Studios are investing heavily in AI tooling
snapshots.body: Deals show studios are adopting generative systems for everything from storyboarding to casting data, which increases the appetite for clear data rights and compliance.

riskPoints.title: Deepfakes are crossing national lines
riskPoints.body: Courts and new bills are reacting to unauthorized deepfakes of public figures, so entertainment teams should create a robust takedown and litigation strategy before AI usage spikes.

riskPoints.title: Politicians keep updating publicity laws
riskPoints.body: As states pass new publicity legislation and Congress debates national guardrails, brands must treat name/image/likeness as a moving target, especially when AI can reproduce famous voices or avatars without permission.

actionItems: Label every deliverable that uses AI-generated visuals or audio so the creative team can track inputs and rights holders.
Include a procedural review section that requires the vendor to document datasets, human oversight, and mitigation plans.
Draft a fallback clause requiring the vendor to pull down any unauthorized synthetic likeness upon notice.

aiLaw.title: What’s in AI Law
aiLaw.description: Stay on top of the executive orders, state bills, and EU directives that are redefining accountability, transparency, and takedowns for AI-driven creative work.

timeline.title: Federal AI blueprint
timeline.body: The White House issued a new executive order aligning AI oversight across agencies, tied to the national AI R&D roadmap and giving NIST more weight for risk-based standards while urging agencies to curb conflicting state laws.

timeline.title: EU AI Act enforcement
timeline.body: The EU AI Act will begin supervision in 2026 with fines up to 7% of worldwide turnover for prohibited systems, and it forces providers to document training data, maintain technical documentation, and run post-launch monitoring.

timeline.title: State and publicity laws
timeline.body: California’s SB-53 and Texas’ SB-20 join proposed federal NO FAKES bills that all require prompt notice and takedowns when likeness or deepfakes stray outside the licensed use.

timeline.title: Congressional disclosure pushes
timeline.body: The Generative AI Copyright Disclosure Act would require creators to label AI-assisted works and detail the datasets used, while similar proposals add transparency requirements for training data provenance.

actionItems: Create an AI policy map that documents which federal/state laws apply to each deliverable, so you can coordinate compliance and reduce contradictory notice obligations.
Update talent releases to anticipate wider jurisdictional requirements (e.g., California biometrics law, Texas protection for children).
Include a procedural review section that requires the vendor to document datasets, human oversight, and mitigation plans.
Draft a fallback clause requiring the vendor to pull down any unauthorized synthetic likeness upon notice.
Track EU and federal reporting duties so you can file systematic risk assessments before deployment.

chainOfTitle.title: Chain of Title Digest
chainOfTitle.description: Financiers, insurers, and distributors won’t underwrite a deal until they see a clean chain of title from creator to release. Use this digest to keep the paperwork straight and avoid last-minute surprises.

highlights.title: Why chain of title matters
highlights.body: Distributors, financiers, and insurers look for an unbroken trail from the underlying writer, creator, or rights holder through every option, assignment, and release before funding a project.

highlights.title: Option and assignment clarity
highlights.body: A stack of option letters or assignments that lack release language or are not properly dated can derail the chain; during diligence you need to confirm each has been properly exercised and expressly assigned.

docs: Original writer and director agreements with express ownership and deliverable descriptions.
Option or first-look letters attached with evidence of exercise, notice, and payment.
Any joint-venture or co-production agreements that allocate IP ownership.
Releases from third parties whose contributions touch the final product (e.g., stock footage, likenesses).
diligenceSteps: Map all prior rights holders, even if the agreement has not yet closed, and confirm releases before calling the project “cleared.”
Match every payment or notice in the stack with the paperwork; missing invoices or unsigned releases are red flags.
Track the territory and media rights on each document; lenders will only finance the media they can insure or distribute.
Document each transfer in a title memorandum so future deals can be closed without re-walking the same chain.

contractRedFlags.title: Contract Red Flags
contractRedFlags.description: A single clause can lock away royalties, rights, or future leverage. Use the snapshots below to flag the terms that need fixing before you sign.

redFlags.title: Perpetual, worldwide grants
redFlags.body: Clauses that assign or license rights “in perpetuity,” “worldwide,” or “in all media now known or hereafter devised” leave creators without room to re-license or renegotiate future formats, so push for narrowing the term and territory.

redFlags.title: Work-for-hire without clarity
redFlags.body: When the contract recites a work-for-hire or assignment but the project elements are undefined, confirm the expressed consideration, whether residuals are owed, and the treatment of future derivatives.

redFlags.title: Undefined deliverables and payment
redFlags.body: Vague statements about “content” or deliverables that omit payment timing invite scope creep; insist on concrete milestones, payment dates, and a revision budget.

redFlags.title: No audit or termination protections
redFlags.body: Agreements that deny audit or terminate only “for cause” trap creators even when the company sits on inaccurate accounting; ask for audit access and a defined cure period.

redFlags.title: Blanket exclusivity or warranty promises
redFlags.body: Broad warranties about infringement or exclusivity should be scoped to the creator’s actual control and limited to the agreed deliverables so the artist is not on the hook for unknown third-party rights.

checklist: Get all underlying assignments or licenses in writing so the lead contract can cite clean chain-of-title pages.
Demand a defined audit clause with a reasonable notice period and caps on audit burdens.
Clarify exit rights: at a minimum, negotiate a short cure period and a termination-for-convenience fall-back.
Make sure all territories, media, and timeframes are enumerated; if not, treat them as limited to the initial campaign.

nilBasics.title: NIL Basics
nilBasics.description: The House settlement, NCAA policy tweaks, and the new clearinghouse are rewriting how deals are filed, disclosed, and taxed.

updates.title: House settlement clears the clouds
updates.body: The House settlement with NIL companies and athletes over $20.5 million of deferred compensation requires a neutral clearinghouse and clearer disclosures before deals over $600 can be booked, making NIL deals easier to audit.

updates.title: NCAA pairs back recruiting limits
updates.body: NCAA policy now lets schools encourage recruits to pursue NIL deals earlier, while still requiring schools to monitor the deals for academic impacts and conflicts.

processItems: Register every deal, endorsement, or appearance with NIL Go so the clearinghouse can confirm compliance and the 1099 thresholds.
Keep a central file on each athlete’s adviser and contracts so that schools can prove compliance and allow quick pause if a misstep is flagged.
Watch the high school and junior college rules that now require disclosure of prominent NIL deals before a player transfers.
actionItems: Have marketing and compliance teams coordinate documents to keep the deal, payment schedule, and deliverables aligned with NCAA guidance.
Stipulate financial reporting requirements (e.g., $600 threshold) for every athlete so the school can file accurate 1099s.

publicityBasics.title: Rights & Publicity Basics
publicityBasics.description: Name, image, and likeness rights are under greater scrutiny as AI can reproduce likenesses instantly. Keep this short guide handy when drafting releases and NIL deals.

definitions.title: Rights of publicity 101
definitions.body: The right of publicity lets individuals control commercial use of their name, image, voice, or likeness, and the doctrine is state-based so obligations, damages, and permissible uses vary significantly.

definitions.title: NIL and publicity overlap
definitions.body: NIL programs and publicity rights intersect because athletes are selling their name, image, or likeness; a clean release must outline the level of control the school or brand retains, and the school must keep the disclosures ready for NCAA review.

aiRisks.title: Deepfake litigation is global
aiRisks.body: Courts in other jurisdictions are already ordering takedowns of unauthorized AI films, while various nations are crafting laws that explicitly shield individuals from synthetic likenesses.

aiRisks.title: Federal bills raise the stakes
aiRisks.body: The NO FAKES Act and Take It Down Act would force platforms to accept takedown notices for synthetic content that violates publicity rights, and content owners can use the same takedown language in their commercial agreements.

reminders.title: Accurate Documentation
reminders.body: Document exactly which rights are licensed (name, voice, live performances, avatar, AI replicas) and the permitted use cases.

reminders.title: Audit NIL Terms
reminders.body: Link NIL deal terms to the publicity release so you can audit for NCAA headlines and avoid unauthorized derivative content.

reminders.title: Takedown Promise
reminders.body: Add a takedown promise that mirrors state/federal law, covering AI-generated content and deepfakes beyond the contract term.

experience.title: Our Experience
experience.body: We have extensive experience in both transactional and litigation matters, ranging from drafting, negotiating, and reviewing complex contracts and corporate documents, intellectual property and licensing matters, and litigating multimillion dollar jury trials. We strongly believe that the key to our success comes from this wide spectrum of experience. For example, because we have successfully litigated multiple breach of contract cases on both sides, we know what the key sticking points and traps are when drafting or reviewing contracts and advising clients, and vice-versa. This experience has proven invaluable and is a key trait that most transactional-only law firms cannot offer. Our clients also have the peace of mind that even for transactional matters, we have the litigation expertise to vigorously fight any disputes that may occur in the future both informally and in court.

clientCentered.title: Client-Centered Practice
clientCentered.body: We take pride in our deep commitment to our clients. Our successful results come not only from our experience, training, and education, but also from our ability to sustain meaningful and collaborative discourse with our clients regarding their cases. As a result, we prioritize regular and frequent communications with our clients from the initial consultation until the conclusion of the case, taking into great consideration our clients’ unique goals and ultimate objectives.

This includes the legal, business, technological, and financial aspects of the entertainment industry. From intellectual property, licensing, right of publicity, corporate, labor and employment, immigration, torts, contracts, and international law, we offer a variety of practices and services to help our entertainment clients successfully achieve both their business and creative objectives. We are based in the entertainment capital of the world, Los Angeles, and are expanding to provide entertainment law services for clients in Korea and China as well.

biography: Jean Kwon, Esq. is an experienced trial lawyer with the rare skill of being trilingual in English, Spanish, and Korean. She has won many jury and court trials and has successfully prosecuted and defended over 3,000 complicated cases involving commercial and residential real estate, business, probate, family, labor, criminal, and civil litigation. Kwon has Juris Doctor Degree from San Fernando Valley College of Law in California, United States; Bachelor of Arts degree from Hankuk University of Foreign Language in Seoul, Korea; and High School degree from Colegio Hipolito Irigoyen, Buenos Aires, Argentina.

Prior to starting her own firm, Kwon worked for several law firms, drafting pleadings and discovery, and appearing in court for the Law Offices of Laurence B. Donoghue, Law Offices of Jiyoung Kym, Law Offices of Jane Chung, and Briskin, Latzanich & Pene LLP.

Kwon is a Member of State Bar of California since June 2008, Member of San Fernando Valley Bar Association; Member of Criminal Courts Bar Association in Los Angeles; Member of California Employment Lawyers Association; Member of Consumer Attorneys Association of Los Angeles, Board Member and Advisory Counsel for the 29th and 30th Korean American Federation of Los Angeles ("KAFLA"); Advisory Counsel for the 30th Election Committee of Korean American Federation of Los Angeles ("KAFLA"); and Legal Counsel for Korean American United Foundation ("KAUF").

Jean Kwon is someone you should meet if your interests lie in storytelling and "filmed" entertainment. Jean Kwon's top-notch boutique law practice in Los Angeles, Cosmic Law Firm, concentrates on the development and production of content for multi-platform use.

Ms. Kwon contemplates telling of her own fascinating and very personal past, from birth in South Korea, through her family's immigration to Argentina and then on to Los Angeles. But her own memoirs may have to wait as she seizes the opportunity to Executive Produce the original screenplay "Tigers from the Sun" written by C.J. Baker. Ms. Kwon has been a renowned legal practitioner for many years, but now aims to expand her repertoire as a lauded producer for bringing the amazing "Tigers" story to light.

biography: John D. Robertson was admitted to the California Bar as a practicing attorney in 1976. Mr. Robertson served as a federal prosecutor (Assistant United States Attorney) for a number of years, as well as a civil litigator in a major law firm before entering private practice and forming his own firm in 1982. Mr. Robertson has over 30 years of experience in criminal defense as well as civil litigation in state and federal courts.

Mr. Robertson received his Juris Doctorate from the nationally ranked Boalt Hall School of Law at the University of California, Berkeley, and was Assistant Editor and an author of the California Law Review at Boalt. Prior to attending law school, Mr. Robertson completed his undergraduate studies at the University of California, Los Angeles, where he graduated with Departmental Highest Honors.

Mr. Robertson served as a Deputy City Attorney for Los Angeles, as well as an Assistant United States Attorney for the Central District of California in the Criminal Division of the United States Department of Justice.

After leaving government service, Mr. Robertson joined the civil litigation and insurance defense law firm of Lewis, D'Amato, Brisbois and Bisgaard in Los Angeles, California as a civil litigator where he specialized in defending lawyers in civil malpractice suits. Subsequent to his employment at the Lewis, D'Amato, Brisbois, and Bisgaard firm, Mr. Robertson started his own private practice in 1982, and has remained in private practice since.

Mr. Robertson continues a civil litigation practice, including representation in breach of contract cases, fraud cases, civil malpractice suits, and professional liability matters, among others. Mr. Robertson also practices in, among other areas, the area of white-collar criminal defense, both in state and federal courts, where his cases have included multi-million dollar frauds, organized crime and racketeering cases, criminal immigration cases, customs smuggling cases, criminal intellectual property infringement cases, computer software counterfeiting cases, wire and mail fraud cases, money laundering cases, criminal tax cases, health care fraud cases, and real estate/fraud mortgage cases, among others.

Mr. Robertson has been active in several state bar associations, has served as Of Counsel and advisor to a number of attorney colleagues and law offices and was formerly a member of the Executive Committee of the Criminal Law Section of the State Bar of California, where he was Chairperson of the Federal Courts Subcommittee. Mr. Robertson also teaches courses on the law and analysis of contracts and contract issues for a program established by Federal District Court Judge to prepare lawyer candidates to pass the California Bar Exam.
